I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming mission in December 2012, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
for Strengthening Capacity for Low-Carbon Development in Ningbo. The concept paper was 
approved on 19 April 2013.1 
 
2.  During the TA fact-finding mission, the impact and outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost estimates, financing arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference 
were agreed with the Ningbo municipal government (NMG) and the Ministry of Finance. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Energy  intensity  reduction  has  been  a  major  government  initiative  to  address 
environmental and climate change impacts from a rapidly growing economy dependent on fossil 
fuels.2 During the 11th Five-Year Plan, 2006–2010, the initiative achieved a reduction of 19.2% 
in energy intensity. The 12th Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015 mandates a further 16% reduction in 
energy  intensity.  The  government  has  initiated  financial  and  policy  incentives  to  stimulate 
investments to improve energy efficiency.  
 
4.  The 12th plan target for reducing energy intensity requires a more strategic approach to 
(i) transform industrial structure from energy-intensive primary industries such as iron and steel 
to high-tech industries with higher value addition and a smaller carbon footprint, and (ii) expand 
the services sector share of the economy. In addition, the energy supply mix needs to be 
transformed from carbon-intensive coal to renewable energy and low-carbon fossil fuels such as 
natural gas.  
 
5.  Ningbo is a city in Zhejiang Province with a population of 7.5 million. It is one of the 
major coastal cities in the PRC, featuring high-tech manufacturing industries and a relatively 
mature and sophisticated finance sector. Manufacturing is dominated by petrochemicals and 
high-tech  products  such  as  precision  machinery,  automobiles,  and  information  technology 
equipment. Yet Ningbo retains many traditional industries, some of which still use obsolete and 
inefficient technologies. Limited access to debt financing, inadequate policies and regulations, 
and weak capacity constrain investment in more efficient technologies, especially constraining 
small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).3   
 
6.  To enhance its efforts favoring low-carbon development, the NMG recently established 
the Office of Climate Change Mitigation under the Ningbo Municipal Development and Reform 
Commission and started in 2012 to formulate its low-carbon development action plan (LCDAP). 
The LCDAP emphasizes improving industrial energy efficiency and expanding the share of 
renewable energy and natural gas. The NMG is keen to introduce market-based instruments to 
promote private sector investments to improve industrial energy efficiency under the LCDAP.  
 
7.  Efforts to improve energy efficiency in Ningbo have so far been driven primarily by 
administrative measures targeting large enterprises, or those that consume more than 100,000 
tons of coal equivalent per year. Under the 12th plan, the NMG has widened the scope by

targeting  enterprises  that  consume  more  than  3,000  tons  of  coal  equivalent  per  year.4 
Combined with concerted efforts to promote energy conservation in commercial and residential 
buildings, in public facilities, and in the provision of urban services such as heating and water 
supply, this lower threshold has brought renewed focus on energy efficiency improvement in 
SMEs.  
 
8.  Ningbo is endowed with excellent renewable energy resources that can help meet local 
energy  needs  and  decarbonize  energy  supply.  Solar  energy  technologies  can  contribute 
significantly to meeting the electricity and heat requirements of residential and public buildings. 
Heat and power plants fueled by biomass and municipal solid waste can provide electricity and 
heat  in  large  urban  areas.  Heat  pumps  to  extract  shallow-ground  geothermal  energy  can 
replace coal boilers in urban heating supply systems, thus decarbonizing heat supply. 
 
9.  The TA supports the PRC’s 12th plan objectives of further reducing energy intensity. It is 
consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for 
the  PRC,  which  emphasizes  environmentally  sustainable growth,  public–private  partnership 
(PPP), and SME development in low-carbon economic sectors.5 It complements and advances 
ADB’s previous interventions and efforts to improve industrial energy efficiency through loans6 
and nonlending projects,7 as well as by establishing emissions-trading markets in Tianjin and 
Shanghai.8 It will help the NMG identify actions and policies to be initiated under its LCDAP to 
accelerate the improvement of industrial energy efficiency and the shift to renewable energy. 
The TA aligns with the priorities of the Ministry of Finance and National Development and 
Reform Commission to develop innovative financing mechanisms to further stimulate energy 
efficiency and renewable and clean energy investments through market-based mechanisms.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will address the NMG’s critical gaps in capacity to design and implement a low-
carbon development strategy through a package of policy, regulations, and financial incentives 
to promote industrial energy efficiency and accelerate a shift to electricity generation using 
distributed renewable energy resources. The TA will enhance the NMG’s capacity to structure 
PPPs for clean energy investments, appropriately allocating responsibilities and risks between 
private and public entities.  
 
12.  The TA will identify technologies and industrial processes to achieve benchmark energy 
efficiency  levels  and  help  the  NMG  establish  a  technology-transfer  mechanism  through 
technology providers such as energy service companies (ESCOs). As ESCOs have technical 
expertise in appropriate technologies but are constrained by lack of access to debt financing, 
the  TA  will  develop  innovative  financial  products9 and  instruments  and  recommend  the 
establishment of a dedicated financing platform to overcome prevailing barriers and mobilize 
financing for energy efficiency projects implemented by ESCOs and SMEs. If successful, it can 
be replicated in other parts of the PRC.   
 
13.  The integration of distributed renewable energy sources poses a number of technical, 
institutional, and financial challenges, as investments must flow to a scattered multitude of small 
renewable energy projects, rather than to a single large project. The role of private investments 
in such projects cannot be emphasized enough. The TA will review the current policy framework 
to  introduce  appropriate  policy  incentives  through  a  transparent  regulatory  regime,  feed-in 
tariffs, and tax incentives to promote private sector investments through PPPs in distributed 
renewable energy.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, secretarial 
assistance, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate and the financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Ningbo  Municipal  Development  and  Reform  Commission  will  be  the  executing 
agency. The Office of Climate Change Mitigation will be the implementing agency and ensure 
that  the  policies  and  strategies  related  to  Ningbo’s  LCDAP  are  communicated  to  the 
consultants. The consultants will work with counterpart staff to ensure effective knowledge 
transfer and information flow between the consultants and the executing and implementing 
agencies. Periodic tripartite meetings of ADB, the executing and implementing agencies, and 
consultants will guide the consultants and review their reports. Workshops and seminars will 
collect comments and discuss consultants’ reports.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will help the NMG identify strategies, 
initiatives, and financial products that need to be launched as early actions under the LCDAP. 
                                                
9  These may include guarantees specifically designed for ESCO transactions, dedicated credit lines that accept 
receivables  under  energy  performance  contracts  as  collateral,  the  buying  back  and  securitization  of  cash 
receivables under energy performance contracts, and direct equity investments.

4  
Phase 2 will support (i) policy formulation and the design of institutional arrangements to deliver 
the financial products identified under phase 1, and (ii) the preparation of PPP transactions in 
clean energy and capacity strengthening in government agencies, financial institutions, and 
potential investors toward encouraging private investments in clean energy.  
 
17.  Due to the urgency of finalizing the Ningbo LCDAP, Phase 1 will be implemented by a 
team  of  individual  consultants  to  be  recruited  by  ADB  and  consisting  of  two  international 
consultants  contracted  for  a  total  of  6  person-months  and  four  national  consultants,  also 
contracted for 6 person-months. For phase 2, ADB will engage a consulting firm to supply two 
international consultants for a total of 5 person-months and five national consultants for 13 
person-months. The TA will be implemented over 18 months, with phase 1 undertaken from 1 
July to 31 December 2013 and phase 2 from 1 January to 31 December 2014. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants and the reporting requirements are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  The  consultants  recruited  for  phases  1  and  2  will  have  extensive  knowledge  and 
expertise regarding (i) energy efficiency project preparation and due diligence, (ii) distributed 
renewable energy technologies and implementation models for distributed renewable energy 
projects,  (iii)  how  to  structure  PPP  projects  for  renewable  energy  and  energy  efficiency 
investments, (iv) financial regulations governing SME financing in the PRC, and (v) structuring 
financial products to overcome the barriers faced by ESCOs.  
 
19.  The consulting firm for phase 2 will be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection 
with  a  quality–cost  ratio  of  90:10,  as  the  experience  and  expertise  of  the  consultants  in 
designing innovative financial products is highly relevant to achieving TA objectives. Selection 
will be based on a simplified technical proposal. Consultant recruitment will accord with ADB 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). TA funds will be 
disbursed in line with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).  
 
20.  Activities for capacity development and information dissemination, such as seminars, 
workshops,  conferences,  and  study  tours,  will  be  finalized  during  TA  implementation  and 
administered  by  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies.  The  consultants  will  prepare 
capacity  building  materials  and  facilitate  knowledge  transfer  on  key  aspects  of  the  TA  to 
stakeholders in Ningbo as well as to relevant central government officials.  
 
21.  The  phase  1  consultants  will  submit  an  inception  report  within  2  weeks  of 
commencement, an interim report after 2 months, and a draft final report after 4 months. The 
final report of phase 1 will be submitted 2 weeks after receiving ADB comments. The phase 2 
consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1 month after signing the consulting contract, 
(ii) a midterm report 6 months after the commencement of consulting services, (iii) a draft final 
report 1 month before TA completion, and (iv) a final report within 1 month after receiving 
feedback from the executing and implementing agencies and ADB on the draft final report. 
 
22.  All  TA  deliverables  and  progress  reports  will  be  written  in  English.  The  national 
consultants will be responsible for translating documents into Chinese. Three copies of each TA 
deliverable will be submitted to ADB in English, and 10 copies (2 in English and 8 in Chinese) 
will be submitted to the executing and implementing agencies. The deliverables and progress 
reports should address the terms of reference with details appropriate to that stage of the TA.

5 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening Capacity for Low-Carbon Development in 
Ningbo, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

2.  Output 1 will be carried out by a team of individual consultants: (i) a clean energy expert 
and team leader (international, 3 person-months), (ii) an energy efficiency expert (international, 
3 person-months), (iii) three energy efficiency financial experts (national, 3 person-months), and 
(iv) a project coordinator (national, 3 person-months). 
 
3.  Clean energy expert and team leader (international, 3 person-months). The expert 
should have proven international expertise in structuring and assessing clean energy projects 
and providing policy advice. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Guide the implementing agency in developing specific near-term work programs 
under the low-carbon development action plan and in identifying supplementary 
policy actions contributing to the establishment of Ningbo’s long-term carbon 
emission control target.    
(ii)  Identify key economic and industrial sectors that have potential for significant 
energy saving, carbon emission reduction, or renewable energy generation. 
(iii)  Assess the possibility of introducing in Ningbo demand-side management and 
demand-response  measures  to  control  electricity  demand  using  price-  and 
market-based incentive mechanisms. 
(iv)  Recommend  strategies  for  promoting  demand-side  management  to  save 
electricity and manage peak load using energy service companies (ESCOs).

(v)  Based on experience from other provinces, recommend incentive mechanisms 
and regulatory policies building on existing measures to achieve potential energy 
savings through energy efficiency investments. 
(vi)  Review the incentive policies and financial support mechanisms available in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) for supporting energy efficiency investments 
and ESCOs in particular.  
(vii)  Recommend how the NMG can establish a financing platform to support energy 
efficiency investment and facilitate the availability of financing for ESCOs.  
(viii)  Explore with selected high-profile companies active in Ningbo the feasibility of a 
potential government–industry alliance to stimulate energy efficiency and low-
carbon investments through supply chain coordination. 
(ix)  Coordinate  the  activities  of  the  national  consultants  and  propose  a 
comprehensive strategy to implement the key aspects of Ningbo’s low-carbon 
development action plan, including policy recommendations and demonstration 
investment projects in clean energy.  
 
4.  Energy  efficiency  expert (international, 3 person-months). The expert should have 
academic and practical experience in energy policy. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Critically review NMG plans for low-carbon development and the 12th Five-Year 
Plan.  
(ii)  Undertake  a  comprehensive  analysis  of  ESCOs  in  Ningbo  and  identify 
opportunities to help accelerate expansion in the industry.   
(iii)  Disaggregate the energy savings to be achieved by sector, ownership, size of 
enterprise, and location within Ningbo. Estimate the investments required for 
each type of energy efficiency improvement project.  
(iv)  Comprehensively review past and existing studies on distributed renewable clean 
energy  applications  among  Ningbo’s  industrial  parks  and  residential  and 
commercial communities.  
(v)  Disaggregate the renewable and clean energy potential by technology, size of 
project, and likely developer.

(1 person-month each) will be recruited for this position, as it may require expertise in different 
types of financial products. The experts will undertake institutional analyses and feasibility 
studies for different financial products to be launched to support ESCO financing. Tasks will 
include the following: 
(i)  Assess the market potential for different financial products to be launched and 
assess the funding required to introduce them. These products may include 
guarantees specifically designed for ESCO transactions, dedicated credit lines 
that accept as collateral receivables under energy performance contracts, the 
buying back and securitization of cash receivables under energy performance 
contracts,  and  direct  equity  investments. Identify  the  potential  clientele,  their 
expectations, and marketing strategies.    
(ii)  Identify potential financing sources for these products, including public sector 
sources. Assess the different financiers’ expectations for risk and return.    
(iii)  Establish financial models for preliminary financial products to be introduced 
under the ESCO financial platform.   
(iv)  Assess the feasibility of offering financial products through a financial platform 
established in Ningbo by forming partnerships between financial institutions and 
the  NMG.  Compliance  with  government  regulations  on  public  finance  and 
financial market regulations will be taken into account.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(v)  Prepare preliminary business plans taking into account the potential market size, 
financial returns expected, cost of financing, and transaction cost of different 
financial products.   
(vi)  Propose institutional structure, corporate governance, and oversight mechanisms 
to ensure fiduciary controls over the public funds used in the proposed financial 
products. Determine the capacity building needed.  
(vii)  Identify  financial  institutions  that  can  act  as  partners  offering  these  financial 
products and assess the compatibility of these products with the existing financial 
products offered in the PRC market. 
(viii)  Determine the risk profiles of each of the proposed financial products in terms of 
financial  and  credit  risk,  reputational  risk,  and  fiduciary  risk.  Propose 
mechanisms to mitigate these risks to acceptable levels.  
  
6.  Project  coordinator  (national,  3  person-months).  The  coordinator  should  have 
extensive experience in working with development partners and coordinating the activities of 
TA-financed consultants and government policy makers. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Provide TA consultants access to data and government policy documents. 
(ii)  Organize consultation meetings with government policy makers, potential private 
investors, and financial institutions. 
(iii)  Collaborate with the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the implementing agency, 
and other national government agencies, and provide translation services as 
required.  
 
B.  Phase 2 
1.  Output 2: Strategies and Institutional Structures Prepared to Promote 
Public–Private Partnerships in Clean Energy 
7.  Output 2 will be carried out by a team of consultants consisting of (i) a clean energy PPP 
expert (international, 1 person-month), (ii) a regulatory and legal expert (national, 1 person-
month), (iii) a clean energy finance expert (national, 2 person-months), (iv) a renewable energy 
expert (national, 1 person-month), and (v) an energy efficiency expert (national, 1 person-
month). Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Taking  into  account  prevailing  institutional  and  regulatory  arrangements  and 
relevant government policies, devise the possible contractual arrangements that 
can be introduced to promote private investments in clean energy in Ningbo. 
(ii)  Identify  appropriate  types  of  institutional  arrangements  that  are  suitable  for 
implementing  different  types  of  clean  energy  projects  with  private  sector 
participation. These could include the clean energy projects such as distributed 
renewable  energy  investments: (a) rooftop  solar  photovoltaic,  (b) small-scale 
wind  power,  (c)  energy  efficiency  improvement  in  public  buildings, 
(d) optimization of energy consumption in industrial parks, and (e) fuel switching 
to increase the use of cleaner fuels such as natural gas. 
(iii)  Identify  the  role  of  the  government  in  terms  of  (a)  selecting  private  sector 
partners,  (b)  monitoring  the  implementation  of  clean  energy  projects,  (c) 
providing access to land and other essential facilities, and (d) the offtake of 
energy  produced  or  making  payments  for  energy  savings  achieved  and 
operational risk sharing. 
(iv)  Recommend legal and regulatory mechanisms to be adopted to monitor and 
regulate the proposed PPP structures, providing adequate support to the private 
sector while ensuring the intended outputs are delivered.

Appendix 3  13 
(v)  Propose strategies to help potential private sector participants mobilize debt and 
equity  financing  from  financial  markets  by  leveraging  public  sector  funds, 
including ADB public sector loans.   
(vi)  Build  awareness  and  capacity  in  public  officials  and  potential  private  sector 
participants for promoting clean energy investments.   
(vii)  Identify at least five demonstration PPP transactions involving different types of 
clean energy technologies covering both renewable energy and energy efficiency.  
(viii)  Propose detailed implementation plans for demonstration projects, including the 
(a)  procedure  for  selecting  private  sector  partners;  (b)  the  allocation  of  risk 
between public and private sector partners, including the definitions of roles and 
responsibilities  of  the  different  parties;  and  (c)  regulatory  and  monitoring 
mechanisms including third party monitoring. 
(ix)  Undertake  financial  analysis  of  proposed  projects  and  determine  the  public 
sector financial support required, if any, to make them viable and bankable.   
 
2.  Output 3: Innovative Financial Products Developed to Overcome Barriers to 
Energy Efficiency Investments 
8.  Output 3 will be carried out by a team of consultants consisting of a (i) clean energy 
finance  expert  (international,  3  person-months),  (ii)  clean  energy  finance  expert  (national, 
3 person-months), (iii) regulatory and legal expert (national, 1 person-month), and (iv) financial 
market and banking expert (national, 3 person-months). Tasks will include the following:  
(i)  Survey a representative sample of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) 
with  potential  in  renewable  energy  and  energy  efficiency,  including  ESCOs, 
regarding project financing modalities and the barriers in raising the requisite 
financing.  
(ii)  Identify the role of guarantee companies in facilitating financing to clean energy 
SMEs including ESCOs. 
(iii)  Summarize banking regulations and other financial regulations that affect the 
availability of financing to clean energy SMEs, including ESCOs, and the barriers 
and regulatory bottlenecks for extending financing to ESCOs.  
(iv)  Review  government  incentive  policies  for  encouraging  SME  investments  in 
energy efficiency and distributed renewable energy. Determine whether these 
policies meet the critical requirement of making financing available to SMEs to 
undertake the investments.  
(v)  Assess the feasibility of introducing financial products and instruments that have 
potential to address the barriers to mobilizing financing faced by clean energy 
SMEs including ESCOs. This assessment will consider (a) market acceptance of 
the proposed instrument and potential partner institutions likely to be interested in 
introducing  these  ESCO  financing  products,  (b)  these  financial  products’ 
compliance with financial market regulations and other legal requirements, and 
(c) institutional readiness and the capacity of potential partner institutions to 
launch the products to the market. 
(vi)  Design in detail a financial platform to be established in Ningbo to offer these 
financial products through partnerships with financial institutions.   
(vii)  Recommend how public sector and international financing institutions such as 
ADB can leverage private sector financing for clean energy.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
3.  Output 4: Capacity of Government Agencies, Financial Institutions, and 
Potential Investors to Implement Recommended Strategies Developed, and 
Financial Products and Public–Private Partnership Models Devised 
9.  Output 4 will be carried out by a team of consultants consisting of (i) a clean energy PPP 
expert (international, 1 person-month), and (ii) a financial market and banking expert (national, 
1 person-month). Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Build  the  capacity  of  municipal  government  agencies  to  structure  PPP 
transactions in clean energy with emphasis on the role of public sector in PPPs, 
risk allocation between public and private sectors in different PPP transactions, 
ensuring the financial viability of PPP transactions through a judicious mix of 
subsidies and incentive payments, and how to regulate PPP transactions.  
(ii)  Disseminate knowledge and lessons learned in PPP and clean energy from other 
parts of the PRC and other countries to the stakeholders in Ningbo. 
(iii)  Build awareness of PPP transactions in clean energy targeting potential investors 
and private sector players. 
(iv)  Build the capacity of financial institutions present in Ningbo to offer the proposed 
financial products for clean energy investments to SMEs.
